Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)", "alternateName": ["Vestibular schwannoma"]}, "description": "An acoustic neuroma is a type of non-cancerous (benign) brain tumour. Find out about the symptoms, treatments and outlook for this condition.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/acoustic-neuroma/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-02-19T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-02-19T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/acoustic-neuroma/", "name": "Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-03-06T10:43:31+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/acoustic-neuroma/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)"}], "keywords": ["Hearing impairment", "Acoustic neuroma", "Brain tumours"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

An acoustic neuroma is a type of non-cancerous (benign) brain tumour. It's also known as a vestibular schwannoma.

A benign brain tumour is a growth in the brain that usually grows slowly over many years and does not spread to other parts of the body.

Acoustic neuromas grow on the nerve used for hearing and balance, which can cause problems such as hearing loss and unsteadiness.

They can sometimes be serious if they become very large, but most are picked up and treated before they reach this stage.

Acoustic neuromas tend to affect adults aged 30 to 60 and usually have no obvious cause, although a small number of cases are the result of a genetic condition called neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms of an acoustic neuroma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of an acoustic neuroma

An acoustic neuroma may not cause any obvious symptoms at first.

Any symptoms tend to develop gradually and often include:

  • hearing loss that usually only affects 1 ear
  • hearing sounds that come from inside the body (tinnitus)
  • the sensation that you're moving or spinning (vertigo)

A large acoustic neuroma can also sometimes cause:

  • persistent headaches
  • temporary blurred or double vision
  • numbness, pain or weakness on 1 side of the face
  • problems with limb co-ordination (ataxia) on 1 side of the body
  • a hoarse voice or difficulty swallowing
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Getting medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Getting medical advice

See your GP if you have persistent or troublesome symptoms that you're worried could be caused by an acoustic neuroma.

Acoustic neuromas can be difficult to diagnose because the symptoms can be caused by other conditions, such as Ménière's disease.

If your GP thinks you could have an acoustic neuroma, you'll be referred to a hospital or clinic for further tests, such as:

  • hearing tests to check for hearing problems and determine whether they're caused by a problem with your nerves
  • an MRI scan, which uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce a detailed picture of the inside of your head
  • a CT scan, which uses a series of X-rays to create a detailed image of the inside of your head
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatments for acoustic neuromas", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments for acoustic neuromas

There are several different treatment options for an acoustic neuroma, depending on the size and position of your tumour, how fast it's growing and your general health.

The main options are:

  • monitoring the tumour – small tumours often just need to be monitored with regular MRI scans, and the treatments below are generally only recommended if scans show it's getting bigger
  • brain surgery – surgery to remove the tumour through a cut in the skull may be carried out under general anaesthetic if it's large or getting bigger
  • stereotactic radiosurgery – small tumours, or any pieces of a larger tumour that remain after surgery, may be treated with a precise beam of radiation to stop them getting any bigger

All these options carry some risks. For example, surgery and radiosurgery can sometimes cause facial numbness or an inability to move part of your face (paralysis).

Speak to your specialist about the best option for you and what the benefits and risks are.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Outlook for acoustic neuromas", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook for acoustic neuromas

Large acoustic neuromas can be serious because they can sometimes cause a life-threatening build-up of fluid in the brain (hydrocephalus).

But it's rare for them to reach this stage. Many grow very slowly or not at all, and those that grow more quickly can be treated before they become too big.

Even with treatment, symptoms such as hearing loss and tinnitus can persist and affect your ability to work, communicate and drive.

These problems may need additional treatment.

Read more about treating hearing loss and treating tinnitus.

An acoustic neuroma can occasionally return after treatment. This is thought to happen to around 1 in every 20 people who have had surgical removal.

You'll probably continue having regular MRI scans after any treatment to check if the tumour is growing again or coming back.

The 100,000 Genomes Project

If your doctor thinks there could be a genetic cause for your acoustic neuroma, you may be invited to take part in the 100,000 Genomes Project.

Your DNA will be studied to find out more about the cause of your condition.

The aim is to create a new personalised medicine service for the NHS. This should transform the way people are cared for.

Find out if you might be able to take part

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Norovirus (vomiting bug):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Norovirus (vomiting bug)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Norovirus (vomiting bug)", "alternateName": ["Vomiting bug", "Winter vomiting bug"]}, "description": "Read all about norovirus, including how it's spread, what the symptoms are, when to get medical advice and how to stop it spreading.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/norovirus/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-04-23T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-04-23T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/norovirus/", "name": "Norovirus (vomiting bug)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-12-16T18:16:19+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/norovirus/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Norovirus (vomiting bug)"}], "keywords": ["Norovirus infections"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Norovirus, also called the "winter vomiting bug", is a stomach bug that causes vomiting and diarrhoea. It can be very unpleasant, but usually goes away in about 2 days.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check if you have norovirus

The main symptoms of norovirus are:

  • feeling sick (nausea)
  • diarrhoea
  • being sick (vomiting)

You may also have:

  • a high temperature of 38C or above
  • a headache
  • aching arms and legs

The symptoms start suddenly within 1 to 2 days of being infected.

How to treat norovirus yourself

You can usually treat yourself or your child at home.

The most important thing is to rest and have lots of fluids to avoid dehydration.

You should start to feel better in 2 to 3 days.

Find out how to treat diarrhoea and vomiting in children and adults

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

School, nursery or work

Stay off school or work until you have not been sick or had diarrhoea for at least 2 days. This is when you're most infectious.

Do not visit hospitals or care homes during this time.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How norovirus is spread

Norovirus can spread very easily.

You can catch norovirus from:

  • close contact with someone with norovirus
  • touching surfaces or objects that have the virus on them, then touching your mouth
  • eating food that's been prepared or handled by someone with norovirus

Washing your hands frequently with soap and water is the best way to stop it spreading. Alcohol hand gels do not kill norovirus.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Urgent", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Get advice from 111 now if:

  • you're worried about a baby under 12 months
  • your child stops breast or bottle feeding while they're ill
  • a child under 5 years has signs of dehydration – such as fewer wet nappies
  • you or your child (over 5 years) still have signs of dehydration after using oral rehydration sachets
  • you or your child keep being sick and cannot keep fluid down
  • you or your child have bloody diarrhoea or bleeding from the bottom
  • you or your child have diarrhoea for more than 7 days or vomiting for more than 2 days

111 will tell you what to do. They can arrange a phone call from a nurse or doctor if you need one.

Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

Other ways to get help

A GP may be able to help you.

Ask your GP practice for an urgent appointment.

Check with the GP surgery before going in. A GP may speak to you on the phone.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Emergency", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Call 999 or go to A&E if you or your child:

  • vomit blood or have vomit that looks like ground coffee
  • have bright green or yellow vomit
  • might have swallowed something poisonous
  • have a stiff neck and pain when looking at bright lights
  • have a sudden, severe headache or stomach ache
Find your nearest A&E
What we mean by severe pain
Severe pain:
  • always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk
  • you cannot sleep
  • it's very hard to move, get out of bed, go to the bathroom, wash or dress
Moderate pain:
  • always there
  • makes it hard to concentrate or sleep
  • you can manage to get up, wash or dress
Mild pain:
  • comes and goes
  • is annoying but does not stop you doing things like going to work
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}]}
Vaginal discharge:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Vaginal discharge", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Vaginal discharge", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about vaginal discharge, including what's normal, signs of a problem, what can cause unusual discharge and when to get medical advice.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-discharge/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-01-17T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-01-17T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-discharge/", "name": "Vaginal discharge", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-02-04T12:20:59+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-discharge/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Vaginal discharge"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vaginal discharge is normal – most women and girls get it. It's a fluid or mucus that keeps the vagina clean and moist, and protects it from infection.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check if your vaginal discharge is normal

Vaginal discharge usually isn't anything to worry about if it:

  • doesn't have a strong or unpleasant smell
  • is clear or white
  • is thick and sticky
  • is slippery and wet

You can get vaginal discharge at any age.

The amount of discharge varies. You usually get heavier discharge during pregnancy, if you're sexually active or if you're using birth control. It's often slippery and wet for a few days between your periods (when you ovulate).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When it can be a sign of an infection

If your discharge changes – for example, in smell, colour or texture – it might be a sign of an infection.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Discharge Possible cause
Smells fishy bacterial vaginosis
Thick and white, like cottage cheese thrush
Green, yellow or frothy trichomoniasis
With pelvic pain or bleeding chlamydia or gonorrhoea
With blisters or sores genital herpes
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP or go to a sexual health clinic if:

  • your discharge changes colour, smell or texture
  • you produce more discharge than usual
  • you feel itchy or sore
  • you bleed between periods or after sex
  • you get pain when peeing
  • you get pain in the area between your tummy and thighs (pelvic pain)
"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Sexual health clinics can help with abnormal discharge

Sexual health clinics treat problems with the genitals and urine system.

Many sexual health clinics offer a walk-in service, where you don't need an appointment. They'll often get test results quicker than GP practices.

Find a sexual health clinic

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Things you can try", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You can't prevent vaginal discharge

Panty liners can help with heavy or excessive discharge or if you're worried about any smell.

To help prevent irritation, soreness or dryness:

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • wash gently

  • use water and an emollient, such as E45 cream, or plain soap

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not use perfumed soaps or gels

  • do not use deodorants or scented hygiene wipes

  • do not douche

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}]}
Vaginal dryness:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Vaginal dryness", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Vaginal dryness", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about vaginal dryness, including why it happens and what can be done about it.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-dryness/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-11-15T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-11-15T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-dryness/", "name": "Vaginal dryness", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-17T10:37:27+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-dryness/#overview", "description": "Vaginal dryness is when your vagina is less lubricated than normal. It's often caused by a change in your hormone levels.", "text": "

Symptoms of vaginal dryness include a sore and itchy vagina, pain during sex and needing to pee more than usual.

Causes for vaginal dryness include changes to your hormone levels and using perfumed soaps or washes on your vagina.

You can usually treat vaginal dryness yourself with things like vaginal moisturisers, water-based lubricants, and unperfumed soaps and washes.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-dryness/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of vaginal dryness include a sore and itchy vagina, pain during sex and needing to pee more than usual.", "text": "

You may have vaginal dryness if you:

  • feel sore or itchy in and around your vagina
  • feel pain or discomfort during sex
  • need to pee more often than usual
  • keep getting urinary tract infections (UTIs)

These things may make you feel less like you want to have sex.

", "title": "Symptoms of vaginal dryness"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-dryness/#causes", "description": "Causes for vaginal dryness include changes to your hormone levels and using perfumed soaps or washes on your vagina.", "text": "

You can get vaginal dryness if you:

  • go through the menopause
  • are breastfeeding
  • take contraceptive pills or antidepressants
  • have your womb removed (a hysterectomy)
  • have cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy

These things can cause a change in your hormone levels. This change can affect how much vaginal discharge or fluid you have.

You can also have vaginal dryness if you:

  • are not aroused during sex
  • use perfumed soaps, washes or douches in and around your vagina
  • have an underlying condition, such as diabetes or Sj\u00f6gren's syndrome
", "title": "Causes of vaginal dryness"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-dryness/#treatments-summary", "description": "You can usually treat vaginal dryness yourself with things like vaginal moisturisers, water-based lubricants, and unperfumed soaps and washes.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-dryness/#self-care", "description": "You can usually treat vaginal dryness yourself with things like vaginal moisturisers, water-based lubricants, and unperfumed soaps and washes.", "text": "

You can try these things before you see a GP. You can get most of them from a pharmacy without a prescription.


Do

  • use water-based lubricants before sex \u2013 put these in and around your vagina or on your partner's penis

  • use vaginal moisturisers for vaginal dryness \u2013 you can put these inside your vagina to keep it moist

  • use unperfumed soaps and washes around your vagina

  • try to enjoy more foreplay so you feel more aroused during sex


Don't

  • do not use perfumed soaps, washes and any douches in and around your vagina

  • do not put creams or lotions like petroleum jelly inside your vagina as it can cause an infection

  • do not use moisturisers that are not for your vagina

Vaginitis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Vaginitis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Vaginitis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about vaginitis, including information about symptoms, when to see a GP, causes and treatment.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginitis/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-02-03T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-02-03T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginitis/", "name": "Vaginitis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-03-12T20:02:29+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginitis/#overview", "description": "Vaginitis is soreness and swelling in and around the vagina. It's often caused by an infection or irritation.", "text": "

Common symptoms of vaginitis include an itchy and sore vagina, unusual vaginal discharge and pain when peeing or having sex.

Causes of vaginitis include thrush, sexually transmitted infections, changes in your hormone levels and irritation.

Treatment for vaginitis depends on what's causing it. Common treatments include antifungal medicine, antibiotics and hormone treatments.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginitis/#symptoms", "description": "Common symptoms of vaginitis include an itchy and sore vagina, unusual vaginal discharge and pain when peeing or having sex.", "text": "

Symptoms of vaginitis include:

  • an itchy or sore vagina
  • vaginal discharge that's a different colour, smell or thickness to usual
  • vaginal dryness
  • pain when peeing or having sex
  • light vaginal bleeding or spotting
  • sore, swollen or cracked skin around your vagina

You might not have all these symptoms.

", "title": "Check if you have vaginitis"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginitis/#causes", "description": "Causes of vaginitis include thrush, sexually transmitted infections, changes in your hormone levels and irritation.", "text": "

Vaginitis has lots of possible causes.

Your symptoms might give you an idea what's causing it. But do not self diagnose, get medical help if you're worried.

Symptoms: White and lumpy discharge (like cottage cheese), itching and soreness
Possible cause: Thrush

Symptoms: Yellow, green or smelly discharge, pain when peeing or having sex
Possible cause: A sexually transmitted infection like trichomoniasis or chlamydia

Symptoms: A dry, itchy vagina and pain when having sex
Possible cause: Hormone changes from the menopause, breastfeeding or some types of contraception

Symptoms: Itchy, sore patches around your vagina and on other parts of your body
Possible cause: A skin condition like eczema or lichen planus

Vaginitis can also be caused by irritation (for example, from soap), an injury to your vagina or something in your vagina (like a tampon).

Common treatments include antifungal medicine, antibiotics and hormone treatments.", "text": "

Treatment for vaginitis depends on the cause.

For example, you may need:

  • antifungal medicine for thrush
  • antibiotics for a sexually transmitted infection
  • vaginal moisturiser, lubricant or hormone treatment for menopause symptoms
  • steroid medicine for a skin condition
", "title": "Treatments for vaginitis from a doctor"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginitis/#self-care", "description": "Things you can do to help vaginitis include keeping your genital area clean and dry, and wearing loose, cotton underwear.", "text": "

There are things you can do to ease symptoms of vaginitis and reduce your chances of getting it again.


Do

  • wash around your vagina with water and dry thoroughly

  • wear loose, cotton underwear

  • use pads instead of tampons when you're on your period

  • use condoms and lubrication when having sex


Don't

  • do not clean inside your vagina (douching)

  • do not have hot baths

  • do not use scented hygiene products in or around your vagina, such as soaps and deodorants

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP or go to a sexual health clinic if:

  • you have symptoms of vaginitis for the first time
  • you've had vaginitis before, but the symptoms are bothering you a lot, are different to usual or are not getting better
  • you have vaginal discharge that's unusual for you
  • you have symptoms of vaginitis after having sex with a new partner
  • you have other symptoms like feeling hot and shivery or pain in your lower tummy (pelvic pain)

Do not have sex until you've seen a doctor or nurse. You could have a sexually transmitted infection.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Sexual health clinics can help with vaginitis

Sexual health clinics treat problems with the genitals and urine system.

Many sexual health clinics offer a walk-in service, where you do not need an appointment. They'll often get test results quicker than GP surgeries.

Find a sexual health clinic.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What happens at your appointment", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

To find out what's causing your vaginitis, a doctor or nurse may:

  • ask about any sexual partners you have
  • look at the skin around your vagina
  • look inside your vagina (pelvic examination)

Having a pelvic examination

  1. You'll be asked to remove your underwear and lie on your back.
  2. The doctor or nurse will gently put a smooth, tube-shaped tool (speculum) into your vagina to hold it open so they can see inside.
  3. A small cotton bud (swab) may be wiped inside your vagina to check for infections.

You can ask the doctor or nurse to stop at any point if you find it too uncomfortable.

Vasculitis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Vasculitis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Vasculitis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about the main types of vasculitis, with links to more information.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vasculitis/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-06-13T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-06-13T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vasculitis/", "name": "Vasculitis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-05-22T12:15:10+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vasculitis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Vasculitis"}], "keywords": ["Aches,", "pains and soreness", "Swollen glands", "Symptoms and signs", "Kawasaki disease", "Vasculitis", "Abdominal pain"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vasculitis means inflammation of the blood vessels.

Inflammation is\u00a0your immune system's natural response to injury or infection. It causes swelling and can help the body deal with invading germs.

But in vasculitis, for some reason the\u00a0immune system attacks healthy blood vessels, causing them to become\u00a0swollen and narrow.

This may be triggered\u00a0by an infection or a medicine,\u00a0although often the cause is unknown.

Vasculitis can range from a minor problem that just affects the skin, to a more serious illness that causes problems with organs like the heart or kidneys.

There are many types of vasculitis. The rest of this page discusses a range of potential causes.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and vasculitis from Vasculitis UK

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome)", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome)

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, also called Churg-Strauss syndrome,\u00a0is a type of vasculitis that mainly affects adults aged 30 to 45.

It can cause:

  • asthma
  • cold-like symptoms caused by allergies (allergic rhinitis)
  • a high temperature of 38C or above
  • muscle and\u00a0joint pain
  • tiredness
  • loss of appetite and\u00a0weight loss

It\u00a0can also affect the nerves, causing weakness,\u00a0pins and needles or numbness, and sometimes damages the kidneys or heart muscle.

It's usually treated with steroid medicine.

The Vasculitis UK website has more information about\u00a0eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Giant cell arteritis (temporal arteritis)", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Giant cell arteritis (temporal arteritis)

Giant cell arteritis\u00a0is a type of vasculitis that often affects the arteries in the head and neck.\u00a0

It\u00a0mostly occurs in\u00a0adults over the age of 50.

It's sometimes called temporal arteritis because\u00a0the arteries around the temples are often affected.

It can cause:

  • aching and soreness around\u00a0the temples
  • jaw muscle pain while eating
  • headaches
  • double vision\u00a0or vision loss

It also commonly occurs alongside\u00a0polymyalgia rheumatica.

The main treatment is\u00a0steroid medicine.\u00a0

Find out more about giant cell arteritis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)\u00a0

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, also called Wegener's granulomatosis, is a type of vasculitis that mainly affects blood vessels in the nose, sinuses, ears, lungs and kidneys.

It mainly affects middle-aged or elderly people.

It can cause:

  • a high temperature
  • night sweats
  • inflammation of the sinuses (sinusitis)
  • nosebleeds and crusting of the nose
  • shortness of breath\u00a0and\u00a0coughing up blood
  • kidney problems

It's a serious condition that can be fatal if left untreated, as it can lead to organ failure.

It's usually treated with\u00a0steroid medicine\u00a0or other medicines that reduce the activity of the immune system.

Find out more about granulomatosis with polyangiitis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Henoch-Sch\u00f6nlein purpura", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Henoch-Sch\u00f6nlein purpura

Henoch-Sch\u00f6nlein purpura\u00a0is a rare type of vasculitis that usually occurs in children and can affect the skin, kidneys or bowel.

It's thought to be triggered by the body reacting to an infection.

It can cause:

  • a rash that looks like small bruises or reddish-purple spots
  • joint pain
  • tummy (abdominal) pain
  • diarrhoea
  • being sick
  • blood in urine\u00a0or poo

It's not usually serious and tends to get better without treatment.

Find out more about Henoch-Sch\u00f6nlein purpura

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Kawasaki disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Kawasaki disease

Kawasaki disease is a condition that mainly affects children under the age of 5.

The characteristic symptoms are a high temperature that lasts for 5 days or more, with:

  • a rash
  • swollen glands in the neck
  • dry, cracked lips
  • red fingers or toes
  • red eyes

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), a solution of antibodies, and aspirin are the 2 main medicines used to treat Kawasaki disease.

Aspirin is not usually recommended for children under 16, so do not give aspirin to your child unless advised to by their doctor.

Find out more about Kawasaki disease

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Microscopic polyangiitis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Microscopic polyangiitis

Microscopic polyangiitis is a rare and potentially serious long-term type of vasculitis that most often develops\u00a0in middle-aged people.

It can affect any organ, but particularly affects the lungs, kidneys and nerves.

It can cause:

  • a rash
  • shortness of breath\u00a0and\u00a0coughing up blood
  • red and sore eyes
  • pins and needles\u00a0or numbness
  • kidney problems

It's usually treated with\u00a0steroid medicine\u00a0or other medicines that reduce the activity of the immune system.

The Vasculitis UK website has more information about\u00a0microscopic polyangiitis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Polyarteritis nodosa", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Polyarteritis nodosa

Polyarteritis nodosa is a rare\u00a0type of vasculitis that\u00a0particularly affects the arteries supplying the gut, kidneys and nerves.

It tends to develop in childhood or in middle-aged people.

It\u00a0can sometimes be triggered by an infection, such as hepatitis B, but the exact cause is uncertain.

It can cause:

  • muscle and\u00a0joint pain
  • tummy (abdominal) pain, particularly after eating
  • a rash
  • pins and needles\u00a0or numbness
  • bleeding and ulcers\u00a0in the gut

It\u00a0can be very serious if not treated. The main treatment is\u00a0steroid medicine,\u00a0and sometimes other medicines that reduce the activity of the immune system.

The Vasculitis UK website has more information about\u00a0polyarteritis nodosa.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Polymyalgia rheumatica", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Polymyalgia rheumatica\u00a0

Polymyalgia rheumatica is a type of vasculitis that's closely related to\u00a0giant cell arteritis.\u00a0

It\u00a0mostly occurs in\u00a0adults over 50 and is more common in women than men.

It can cause:

  • pain and stiffness in the shoulders, neck and hips, which is often worse after waking up
  • a high temperature
  • extreme tiredness
  • loss of appetite and\u00a0weight loss
  • depression

The main treatment is\u00a0steroid medicine, which\u00a0is usually used in lower doses than for giant cell arteritis.\u00a0

Find out more about polymyalgia rheumatica

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 10, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Takayasu arteritis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Takayasu arteritis

Takayasu arteritis\u00a0is a type of vasculitis that mainly affects young women. It's very rare in the UK.

It affects the main artery from the heart, as well as\u00a0the major arteries branching off it.

It can cause:

  • extreme tiredness
  • a high temperature
  • weight loss
  • muscle and\u00a0joint pain
  • dizziness
  • shortness of breath
  • painful, numb or cold limbs

Treatment is usually with\u00a0steroid medicine.

The Vasculitis UK website has more information about\u00a0Takayasu arteritis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 11, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Other types of vasculitis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Other types of vasculitis\u00a0

Beh\u00e7et's disease

Beh\u00e7et's disease\u00a0typically\u00a0causes\u00a0mouth ulcers and genital ulcers, and is more common in people from Greece, Turkey, the Middle East, China and Japan.

Buerger's disease

Buerger's disease\u00a0affects blood vessels in the legs and arms, leading to reduced blood flow to the hands and feet. It's closely linked to smoking.

Cogan's syndrome

Cogan's syndrome\u00a0is inflammation of the blood vessels in the inner ears and eyes.

Cryoglobulin-associated vasculitis

Cryoglobulin-associated vasculitis\u00a0is associated with proteins in the blood called cryoglobulins and can occur after a hepatitis C infection.

It causes\u00a0a rash on the lower limbs,\u00a0joint pain, nerve damage, tummy (abdominal) pain and kidney\u00a0problems.

Hypersensitivity vasculitis

Hypersensitivity vasculitis\u00a0is\u00a0usually caused by a reaction to a medicine, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or certain antibiotics, and results in a temporary rash.

Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

Primary angiitis of the central nervous system\u00a0is\u00a0inflammation of the blood vessels in the brain.

Rheumatoid vasculitis

Rheumatoid vasculitis\u00a0is vasculitis associated with\u00a0rheumatoid arthritis.

Vomiting blood (haematemesis):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Vomiting blood (haematemesis)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Vomiting blood (haematemesis)", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about what to do if you're vomiting blood. Vomiting blood is a medical emergency and requires immediate medical assistance. Go to your GP surgery or nearest A&E department.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vomiting-blood/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-10-04T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-10-04T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vomiting-blood/", "name": "Vomiting blood (haematemesis)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-10-09T13:31:18+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vomiting-blood/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Vomiting blood (haematemesis)"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vomiting blood (haematemesis) could be a sign of a serious problem .

You should go to your GP surgery or nearest A&E department.

The amount and colour of blood can vary. For example:

  • you may have vomited large amounts of bright red blood
  • there may be streaks of blood in your vomit, mixed with food
  • there may be what look like coffee grounds in your vomit, which means the blood has been in your stomach for a few hours

Keep a small sample of the vomit to show a GP or the doctor treating you. It will give them a better idea of what's wrong.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What to expect when you see a doctor", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What to expect when you see a doctor

Unless you're generally well and the cause is obvious to a doctor – for example, you have swallowed blood from a nosebleed – you should be admitted to hospital straight away for tests.

These will include blood tests and an endoscopy. An endoscopy is where a long, thin, flexible tube that has a light and camera at one end is used to look inside your digestive tract.

It's important to confirm whether the blood you've vomited has come from your stomach or food pipe (oesophagus) or if you have coughed it up from your airways or lungs.

Find out more about coughing up blood.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Common causes of vomiting blood", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Common causes of vomiting blood

If you vomit blood, it means there may be bleeding somewhere in your food pipe, stomach or the first part of your small intestine (duodenum).

This is a summary of the most likely causes of blood in vomit. Do not use this list to diagnose yourself – always see a GP or go to A&E.

Stomach ulcer or severe gastritis

If you vomit blood and also have a burning or gnawing pain in your tummy (stomach), the most likely causes are a stomach ulcer or severe inflammation of the stomach lining (gastritis).

Bleeding happens when the ulcer or inflammation damages an artery.

Oesophageal varices

Oesophageal varices are enlarged veins in the lower part of the food pipe (oesophagus). They bleed, but do not usually cause any pain.

They're often caused by alcoholic-related liver disease. If a GP or A&E doctor suspects oesophageal varices are the cause of blood in your vomit, you'll need to be admitted to hospital immediately.

Severe gastro-oesophageal reflux disease

Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) is where acid leaks out of the stomach and up into your food pipe (oesophagus).

If you have severe GORD, the acid can irritate the lining of your oesophagus and cause bleeding.

Tear in the food pipe (oesophagus)

Prolonged retching can tear the lining of your oesophagus, which can also result in bleeding.

Swallowed blood

It's possible to swallow blood in certain circumstances – for example, after a severe nosebleed.

These conditions may also cause you to have blood in your poo, which can make it look black and like tar.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Less common causes of vomiting blood", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Less common causes of vomiting blood

Less commonly, blood in your vomit may be caused by:

  • swallowing a poison – such as corrosive acid or arsenic
  • a blood condition – such as a reduced number of platelets in the blood (thrombocytopenia), leukaemia, haemophilia or anaemia
  • oesophageal cancer or stomach cancer – these types of cancer are uncommon, but they may be suspected if you're over 55 and you've also lost a lot of weight
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Von Willebrand disease:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Von Willebrand disease", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Von Willebrand disease", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is a condition that causes heavy or long-lasting bleeding. Find out about the symptoms, causes and treatments for it.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/von-willebrand-disease/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-09-02T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-09-02T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/von-willebrand-disease/", "name": "Von Willebrand disease", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-09T13:24:13+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/von-willebrand-disease/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Von Willebrand disease"}], "keywords": ["Haemophilia", "Blood", "Bleeding", "Desmopressin", "Nosebleeds", "Women", "Heavy periods"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is a common inherited condition that can make you bleed more easily than normal.

People with VWD have a low level of a substance called von Willebrand factor in their blood, or it does not work very well.

Von Willebrand factor helps blood cells stick together (clot) when you bleed. If there's not enough of it or it does not work properly, it takes longer for bleeding to stop.

There's currently no cure for VWD, but it does not usually cause serious problems and most people with it can live normal, active lives.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of von Willebrand disease", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of von Willebrand disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The symptoms of VWD\u00a0may start at any age. They can range from very mild and barely noticeable to frequent and severe.

The\u00a0main symptoms are:

  • large bruises or bruising easily
  • frequent or long-lasting\u00a0nosebleeds
  • bleeding gums
  • heavy or long-lasting bleeding from\u00a0cuts
  • in women,\u00a0heavy periods and\u00a0bleeding during or after labour
  • heavy or long-lasting bleeding after a tooth removal or surgery

In some people, there's also a small\u00a0risk of\u00a0problems such as bleeding in the gut (causing bleeding from the bottom) and painful bleeds into joints and muscles.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When\u00a0to get medical help", "text": "When\u00a0to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

See a GP if you have symptoms of VWD, especially if someone else in your family has it.

If the GP thinks you might have a bleeding problem, they may refer you to a\u00a0hospital specialist for\u00a0blood tests to check for conditions like VWD. Tell your doctor if you have a history of it in your family.

If you've already been diagnosed with VWD, contact your specialist if:

  • you keep getting bleeds
  • you've had a heavy bleed
  • you're pregnant or planning\u00a0a pregnancy\u00a0

Go to\u00a0A&E if you have very heavy bleeding or bleeding that does not stop.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment\u00a0and lifestyle advice for von Willebrand disease", "text": "Treatment\u00a0and lifestyle advice for von Willebrand disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There's currently no cure for VWD, but it can usually be controlled with medicines and some simple lifestyle measures.

Treating and preventing bleeds

If you're bleeding, applying pressure to\u00a0the wound (or pinching the soft part of your nose if you have a nosebleed) for a few minutes may be all you need to do.

Your doctor\u00a0may also give you medicine to help stop bleeding when it happens.

There are 3 main medicines\u00a0that can help stop bleeds:

  • desmopressin \u2013 available as a nasal spray or injection
  • tranexamic acid \u2013 available as tablets, a mouthwash or an injection
  • von Willebrand factor concentrate \u2013\u00a0available as an injection

These medicines\u00a0can also be used before a procedure or\u00a0operation to reduce the risk of bleeding. If you have severe VWD, you may need to\u00a0take them regularly to help prevent serious bleeds.

If your doctor recommends medicine, talk to them about the best option for you and ask about the side effects of each medicine.

Treatments for\u00a0heavy periods

If VWD causes you to have heavy periods, speak to your GP or specialist about treatments to help\u00a0control the bleeding.

These include:

  • oral contraceptive pill
  • intrauterine\u00a0system (IUS)
  • tranexamic acid tablets
  • desmopressin nasal spray
  • in severe cases, von Willebrand factor concentrate

Read more about treatments for heavy periods

General advice

If you have VWD, you should:

  • tell your\u00a0surgeon or dentist about it if you're due to have a procedure or operation\u00a0\u2013 you may need to take medicine to reduce the risk of bleeding\u00a0before and afterwards
  • tell your doctor or nurse\u00a0about your\u00a0VWD if you\u00a0need a vaccination \u2013 they\u00a0can give the injection just under your skin to avoid painful bleeding in your muscles
  • avoid\u00a0aspirin and anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen unless your specialist advises you it's safe to use them, as these can make bleeding worse\u00a0\u2013 use other medicines such as paracetamol\u00a0instead
  • ask your specialist if there are any activities you need to avoid \u2013 you should be able to take part in most sports and activities, but it's best to check first
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Types\u00a0of von Willebrand disease", "text": "Types\u00a0of von Willebrand disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There are\u00a0several types of VWD.

The main types are:

  • type 1 \u2013 the mildest and most common type. People with type 1 VWD have a reduced level of von Willebrand factor in their blood. Bleeding is\u00a0mostly only a problem if you have surgery, injure yourself, or have a tooth removed.
  • type 2 \u2013\u00a0in people with this type of VWD, von Willebrand factor does not work properly. Bleeding tends to be more frequent and heavier\u00a0than in type 1.
  • type 3 \u2013 the most severe\u00a0and rarest type. People with type 3 VWD have very low levels of von Willebrand factor, or none at all. Bleeding from the mouth, nose and gut is common, and you can have joint and muscle bleeds after an injury.

These 3 types are all inherited.

There's also a rare type that is not inherited called "acquired von Willebrand disease". This can start at any age and is usually associated with other conditions that affect the blood, immune system or heart.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How\u00a0von Willebrand disease is inherited", "text": "How\u00a0von Willebrand disease is inherited", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

VWD is often caused by a fault in the gene involved in the production of von Willebrand factor.

The\u00a0type of VWD a person is born with mostly depends on whether they inherit copies of this faulty gene from 1 or both parents.

  • If a parent has a genetic fault that causes VWD \u2013 there's a 1 in 2 (50%) chance of a child having type 1 or type 2 VWD, and no chance of them having type 3 VWD.
  • If both parents have a fault in the VWD gene \u2013 there's a 1 in 2 (50%) chance of a child being a carrier like their parents and a 1 in 4 (25%) chance of them having type 3 VWD.

The chances of inheriting type 1 VWD can also be affected by\u00a0other things, including\u00a0blood group.\u00a0People with blood group O are more often affected than people with blood group A or B.

This means it's not always easy to predict whether a child might inherit it from their parents.

Parents who are carriers of a faulty VWF gene may not have symptoms themselves.

Speak to your specialist if you have VWD and are thinking about having a baby. If you have a family history of VWD and think you might be affected, you should ideally have tests before you get pregnant.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Pregnancy\u00a0and von Willebrand disease", "text": "Pregnancy\u00a0and von Willebrand disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You can have children if you have VWD, even if it's severe. But there's a risk of:

  • your child being born with VWD
  • you having heavy bleeding during or after labour

Speak to your doctor about your options if you're planning to have a baby. They may suggest\u00a0genetic testing to see if your baby is at risk of being born with VWD.

You can also have tests towards the end of your pregnancy to check the level of von Willebrand factor in your blood. Medicine to help prevent bleeding during labour will be offered if your level is low.

You'll probably be advised to give birth in a specialist hospital in case there are any problems. Most women can give birth either vaginally or\u00a0by\u00a0caesarean section. It's rare for babies with VWD to have any problems with bleeding during birth.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service", "text": "Information about you", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you have VWD, your clinical team will pass information about you on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

The NCARDRS helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat VWD. You can opt out of the register at any time.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Vulvodynia (vulval pain):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Vulvodynia (vulval pain)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Vulvodynia (vulval pain)", "alternateName": ["Vaginal pain"]}, "description": "Read about the symptoms of vulvodynia, what the treatments are, and what else can cause vulval pain.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-05-24T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-05-24T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/", "name": "Vulvodynia (vulval pain)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-17T10:44:52+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/#overview", "description": "Vulvodynia is long-lasting pain in the vulva, the area around the opening of the vagina.", "text": "

The main symptom of vulvodynia is pain in and around the vulva. The pain may be there all the time or it may come and go.

Treatments for vulvodynia include painkilling gels you can get from a pharmacy, stronger prescription painkillers, physiotherapy and talking therapy.

A cause for vulvodynia cannot always be found. Sometimes it\u2019s caused by nerve damage from surgery or giving birth.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/#symptoms", "description": "The main symptom of vulvodynia is pain in and around the vulva. The pain may be there all the time or it may come and go.", "text": "

The main symptom is persistent pain in and around the vulva and vagina.\u00a0The vulva usually looks normal.

The pain may be:

  • burning, stinging, throbbing or sore
  • triggered by touch, such as during sex or when inserting a tampon
  • constantly in the background
  • worse when sitting down
  • limited to part of the vulva, such as the opening of the vagina
  • more widespread \u2013 sometimes it can spread over the whole genital area and the anus

Some women also have problems such as\u00a0vaginismus (where the muscles around the vagina tighten involuntarily),\u00a0interstitial cystitis (a painful bladder condition),\u00a0painful periods and\u00a0irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Having persistent vulval pain can affect relationships, reduce sex drive, and cause\u00a0low mood and depression.

Pain in the genital area is often embarrassing to talk about and can make you feel isolated.

", "title": "Symptoms\u00a0of vulvodynia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatments for vulvodynia include painkilling gels you can get from a pharmacy, stronger prescription painkillers, physiotherapy and talking therapy.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/#self-care", "description": "Treatments for vulvodynia include painkilling gels you can get from a pharmacy, stronger prescription painkillers, physiotherapy and talking therapy.", "text": "

Lifestyle changes may help reduce symptoms:

  • wear cotton underwear and loose-fitting skirts or trousers
  • avoid scented hygiene products, such as feminine wipes, bubble bath and soap\u00a0(an emollient\u00a0is a good substitute for soap)
  • apply cool gel packs to\u00a0your vulva to soothe the pain
  • use petroleum jelly before swimming to protect the vulva from chlorine
  • try not to avoid sex or touching your vulva completely, as this may make your vulva more sensitive. If sex is painful, try to find a position that's more comfortable, or do other sexually intimate activities together until you have sought advice if penetration is painful
  • try to reduce\u00a0stress, as it can increase the pain of vulvodynia
  • for pain when sitting, using a doughnut-shaped cushion can help
", "title": "Things you can do to help with vulvodynia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatments for vulvodynia include painkilling gels you can get from a pharmacy, stronger prescription painkillers, physiotherapy and talking therapy.", "text": "

A combination of treatments can often help relieve the symptoms of vulvodynia and reduce its impact on your life.

Vulval gels and lubricants you can buy

Apply an\u00a0anaesthetic\u00a0gel, such as lidocaine, up to 20 minutes before sex. This may make sex more comfortable.

To stop the gel getting on your partner, either wipe it off just before having sex or ask your partner to wear a\u00a0condom (if using condoms, use latex-free ones as latex condoms can be damaged by lidocaine).

If your pain is more constant, apply lidocaine regularly throughout the day. You can also use it overnight.

You can buy tubes of 5% lidocaine gel, cream or ointment over the counter from a pharmacy, although it's a good idea to get a doctor's advice before trying it.

Read the instructions carefully before you use it.

Vaginal lubricants and aqueous cream (also available over the counter from pharmacies and supermarkets) may soothe the area and help moisturise the vulva if it's dry.

Speak to a pharmacist about these treatments.

Prescription\u00a0medicine from a doctor

Conventional painkillers like\u00a0paracetamol will not usually relieve the pain of vulvodynia.

But several prescription medicines may help, including:

  • antidepressants called amitriptyline\u00a0and nortriptyline\u00a0\u2013\u00a0possible side effects include\u00a0drowsiness, weight gain and\u00a0dry mouth
  • anti-epilepsy medicines called gabapentin and pregabalin\u00a0\u2013 possible side effects include\u00a0dizziness, drowsiness and weight gain

Your doctor will probably start you on a low dose and gradually increase it until your pain subsides.

You may need to take the medicine for several months.

If you have\u00a0pain in a specific area of\u00a0your vulva, injections of local anaesthetic and\u00a0steroids into a nearby nerve may\u00a0provide temporary pain relief.

Physiotherapy

A\u00a0physiotherapist\u00a0can teach you some pelvic floor exercises (such as squeezing and releasing your pelvic floor muscles) to help relax the muscles around your vagina.

Another technique to relax the muscles in the vagina and desensitise it involves using vaginal trainers.

These are smooth cones of gradually increasing size and length that can be inserted into your vagina in the privacy of your own home.

Some physiotherapists may also suggest trying\u00a0TENS (transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation) to reduce your pain.\u00a0

This is where a machine is used to deliver a mild electrical current to the painful area.

Therapy\u00a0and counselling

Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is a type of therapy that aims to help you manage your problems by changing how you think and act.

It can often help women cope with the impact that vulvodynia has on their life.

CBT focuses on the problems and difficulties you have, and looks for practical ways you can improve your state of mind on a daily basis.

Psychosexual counselling is helpful when pain is affecting intimacy between you and your partner.

This is a type of therapy that aims to address problems such as fear and anxiety about sex, and restore a physical relationship with your partner.

Surgery

Surgery to remove part of the vulva is done in very rare cases.

But the pain can come back and it's usually not recommended.

", "title": "Treatments\u00a0for vulvodynia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/#causes", "description": "A cause for vulvodynia cannot always be found. Sometimes it\u2019s caused by nerve damage from surgery or giving birth.", "text": "

Vulvodynia may be caused by a problem with the nerves supplying the vulva.

This nerve damage could be caused by:

  • previous surgery
  • childbirth
  • trapped nerves\u00a0
  • a history of severe vaginal thrush

Vulvodynia is not contagious. It\u00a0has nothing to do with personal hygiene and is not a sign of cancer.

Sometimes the exact cause of vulvodynia is never found.

", "title": "Possible\u00a0causes of vulvodynia"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vulvodynia/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Vulvodynia (vulval pain)"}], "keywords": ["Sex advice", "Cognitive behavioural therapy", "Counselling", "Women", "Aches,", "pains and soreness", "Vulva", "Psychological therapy", "Sjogren's syndrome", "Vagina", "Physiotherapy", "Skin"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vulvodynia is persistent, unexplained pain in the vulva. The vulva is the female genital area including the skin surrounding the opening of the vagina.

It can happen to women of all ages.

Vulvodynia can become a long-term problem that's very distressing to live with, but much can be done to help relieve the pain.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of vulvodynia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The main symptom is persistent pain in and around the vulva and vagina.\u00a0The vulva usually looks normal.

The pain may be:

  • burning, stinging, throbbing or sore
  • triggered by touch, such as during sex or when inserting a tampon
  • constantly in the background
  • worse when sitting down
  • limited to part of the vulva, such as the opening of the vagina
  • more widespread \u2013 sometimes it can spread over the whole genital area and the anus

Some women also have problems such as\u00a0vaginismus (where the muscles around the vagina tighten involuntarily),\u00a0interstitial cystitis (a painful bladder condition),\u00a0painful periods and\u00a0irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Having persistent vulval pain can affect relationships, reduce sex drive, and cause\u00a0low mood and depression.

Pain in the genital area is often embarrassing to talk about and can make you feel isolated.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to get medical advice

See a GP or visit\u00a0your local sexual health clinic if you have persistent vulval pain.

Find a sexual health clinic.

Vulvodynia is unlikely to get better on its own and some of the treatments are only available on prescription.

There are also some other causes of\u00a0vulval pain that need to be ruled out.

Your doctor will ask about your symptoms and may touch your vulva lightly with the tip of a cotton bud to see if this causes pain.

A swab may also be taken to check for health problems such as infections.

Women with vulval pain can often have it for many years before they get a diagnosis and treatment.

Ask a GP for a referral to a specialist vulval clinic if the pain persists.

  • try to reduce\u00a0stress, as it can increase the pain of vulvodynia

To stop the gel getting on your partner, either wipe it off just before having sex or ask your partner to wear a\u00a0condom (if using condoms, use latex-free ones as latex condoms can be damaged by lidocaine).

Prescription\u00a0medicine from a doctor

Conventional painkillers like\u00a0paracetamol will not usually relieve the pain of vulvodynia.

But several prescription medicines may help, including:

  • antidepressants called amitriptyline\u00a0and nortriptyline\u00a0\u2013\u00a0possible side effects include\u00a0drowsiness, weight gain and\u00a0dry mouth
  • anti-epilepsy medicines called gabapentin and pregabalin\u00a0\u2013 possible side effects include\u00a0dizziness, drowsiness and weight gain

Your doctor will probably start you on a low dose and gradually increase it until your pain subsides.

You may need to take the medicine for several months.

If you have\u00a0pain in a specific area of\u00a0your vulva, injections of local anaesthetic and\u00a0steroids into a nearby nerve may\u00a0provide temporary pain relief.

Physiotherapy

A\u00a0physiotherapist\u00a0can teach you some pelvic floor exercises (such as squeezing and releasing your pelvic floor muscles) to help relax the muscles around your vagina.

Another technique to relax the muscles in the vagina and desensitise it involves using vaginal trainers.

These are smooth cones of gradually increasing size and length that can be inserted into your vagina in the privacy of your own home.

Some physiotherapists may also suggest trying\u00a0TENS (transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation) to reduce your pain.\u00a0

This is where a machine is used to deliver a mild electrical current to the painful area.

Therapy\u00a0and counselling

Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is a type of therapy that aims to help you manage your problems by changing how you think and act.

It can often help women cope with the impact that vulvodynia has on their life.

CBT focuses on the problems and difficulties you have, and looks for practical ways you can improve your state of mind on a daily basis.

Psychosexual counselling is helpful when pain is affecting intimacy between you and your partner.

This is a type of therapy that aims to address problems such as fear and anxiety about sex, and restore a physical relationship with your partner.

Surgery

Surgery to remove part of the vulva is done in very rare cases.

But the pain can come back and it's usually not recommended.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Possible\u00a0causes of vulvodynia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vulvodynia may be caused by a problem with the nerves supplying the vulva.

This nerve damage could be caused by:

  • previous surgery
  • childbirth
  • trapped nerves\u00a0
  • a history of severe vaginal thrush

Vulvodynia is not contagious. It\u00a0has nothing to do with personal hygiene and is not a sign of cancer.

Sometimes the exact cause of vulvodynia is never found.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Other\u00a0causes of vulval pain

Pain in the vulva is not always vulvodynia.

It can have a number of other causes, such as:

  • persistent vaginal thrush\u00a0or other vaginal infections
  • sensitivity to soap, bubble bath or\u00a0medicated creams\u00a0
  • a drop in the hormone oestrogen, causing dryness of the vulva and vagina, particularly during the\u00a0menopause
  • a recurrent herpes infection
  • lichen sclerosus or lichen planus, skin conditions that\u00a0can cause intense irritation and soreness of the vulva
  • in rare cases, Beh\u00e7et's disease (a\u00a0disorder of the blood vessels that can cause genital ulcers) or Sj\u00f6gren's syndrome (a disorder of the immune system that can cause vaginal dryness)

Your doctor may want to rule out these conditions before treating you for vulvodynia.

Some women can have a combination of problems, such as recurrent thrush and vulvodynia.

Both of these need proper treatment to reduce pain.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Support\u00a0groups and more information

Living with a long-term painful condition like vulvodynia can be frustrating and stressful.

You may find it useful to contact a support group for more\u00a0information and\u00a0advice, or to get in touch with other women who have vulvodynia.

The\u00a02 main support groups are:

  • the Vulval Pain Society
  • the Pelvic Pain Support Network
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Disorders of consciousness:

consciousness, or impaired consciousness, is a state where consciousness is affected by an injury to the brain.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/disorders-of-consciousness/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-08-06T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-08-06T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item":
