Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegene:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)", "alternateName": ["Wegener's granulomatosis"]}, "description": "Find out about granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), including what the symptoms are, why it happens and how it's treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/granulomatosis-with-polyangiitis/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-07-30T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-07-30T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/granulomatosis-with-polyangiitis/", "name": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-19T14:16:10+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/granulomatosis-with-polyangiitis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)"}], "keywords": ["Blood", "Deep vein thrombosis", "Urine tests", "Nose", "Lungs and airways"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a rare\u00a0condition where the blood vessels become inflamed. It mainly affects the ears, nose, sinuses, kidneys and lungs.

Anyone can get it, including children, but it's most common in adults and\u00a0older people.

GPA can be very serious but, with medicine, most people are able to manage the symptoms and keep the condition under control.

GPA\u00a0used to be called\u00a0Wegener's granulomatosis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of GPA

GPA can cause a range of symptoms depending on which parts of the body are affected.

General symptoms include:

  • tiredness
  • a high temperature
  • muscle weakness
  • loss of appetite
  • unintentional weight loss\u00a0
  • joint pain

Ear, nose and throat problems:

  • a blocked or runny nose
  • nosebleeds
  • crusts around the nostrils
  • face pain (sinusitis)
  • earache
  • hearing loss

Lung problems:

  • a\u00a0cough that does not go away
  • shortness of breath
  • wheezing
  • chest pain

Kidney problems:

  • blood in pee
  • high blood pressure
  • inflammation of the kidneys (glomerulonephritis)

Skin problems:

  • rashes
  • lumps
  • small\u00a0purple spots

Eye problems

  • irritated eyes (conjunctivitis)
  • swollen eyelids
  • double vision

Gut problems:

  • tummy pain
  • diarrhoea
  • blood in poo

If it's not treated, GPA can cause permanent damage to some parts of the body. For example, it can change the shape of the nose or stop the kidneys working properly.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to get medical advice

See a GP\u00a0if you have symptoms of GPA, especially if they do not go away.

The GP can do some simple checks to try to find out what's causing your symptoms and can refer you to a hospital specialist for further tests, if needed.

If you've already been diagnosed with GPA, contact your doctor if any of your old symptoms come back or you get any new symptoms.\u00a0Your treatment may need to be changed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Tests\u00a0for GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Tests\u00a0for GPA

GPA can be difficult to diagnose. It causes a range of symptoms that are often similar to other common conditions.

A specialist doctor may:

  • ask about your\u00a0symptoms and examine the affected parts of your body
  • do a urine test to\u00a0check how well your kidneys are working
  • do a blood test to look for substances called\u00a0ANCAs (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies), which are\u00a0thought to be involved in\u00a0GPA
  • remove a small sample of tissue\u00a0(a biopsy) and check it for signs of inflammation
  • organise an X-ray, CT scan\u00a0or MRI scan to\u00a0look at the affected\u00a0parts of the body in more detail
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for GPA

GPA is thought to be caused by a problem with the immune system. It's treated with medicines that reduce the activity of the immune system.

There are 3 main stages of treatment.

Stage 1: Bringing the condition under control

The first aim of treatment is to bring the symptoms of GPA under control. This usually involves:

  • having injections of a medicine called cyclophosphamide every 2 or 3 weeks, or taking it as tablets every day (occasionally, other medicines \u2013\u00a0such as methotrexate, mycophenolate mofetil or rituximab \u2013\u00a0may be used instead)
  • taking steroid\u00a0tablets\u00a0every day or having\u00a0steroid injections into your blood\u00a0at\u00a0the same time as\u00a0the\u00a0cyclophosphamide injections

These\u00a0are all strong medicines, so make sure you discuss the possible side effects with your doctor.

Some people also need a\u00a0plasma exchange, where a machine is used to filter\u00a0the blood to remove the harmful antibodies linked to GPA.

This first stage of treatment lasts until your symptoms are under control, which usually takes a few months.

Stage 2: Keeping the condition under control

Once the condition is under control, treatment aims to stop your symptoms coming back. This usually involves:

  • stopping treatment\u00a0with cyclophosphamide
  • taking\u00a0medicine that helps "calm" (or control) your body's immune system, such as an immunosuppressant like methotrexate or azathioprine
  • taking steroid tablets every day

This stage of treatment typically lasts for 2 to 5 years.

Stage 3: Treating\u00a0symptoms if they come back

If your symptoms come back or you\u00a0get new symptoms (a relapse) at any point, your treatment may be changed or restarted.

For example, your dose of steroids may be increased, and you may need to have more cyclophosphamide injections, start treatment with rituximab, or possibly have a course of plasma exchange.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Living\u00a0with GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Living\u00a0with GPA

GPA is a serious condition but, with treatment, it can usually be kept under control.

You might need to take medicine for several years and you'll have regular check-ups in case your symptoms come back.

About\u00a0half of people with GPA have a relapse\u00a0within a few years\u00a0of their treatment stopping. Further treatment can help bring\u00a0the condition back under control if this happens.

If\u00a0GPA is\u00a0severe or\u00a0is not treated quickly, there\u00a0is a risk that life-threatening problems could develop, such as permanent damage to the kidneys that may require a kidney transplant.

This is why it's important to contact your doctor as soon as possible if your symptoms come back or you start getting new ones.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Support\u00a0and advice if you have GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Support\u00a0and advice if you have GPA

For\u00a0more information and advice, you may find it useful to\u00a0check the Vasculitis UK website.

Vasculitis UK is an organisation for people with vasculitis (inflammation of the blood vessels). GPA is a type of vasculitis.

The Vasculitis UK website has information about living and coping with vasculitis, including advice about general health, benefits and insurance.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of GPA

The exact cause of GPA is unknown.

It may be due to problems with the immune system, which makes it attack and inflame the blood vessels. But it's not clear why this happens.

People with GPA may have a gene that makes them more likely to\u00a0get the condition.\u00a0It might then be triggered by something like a virus or bacterial infection, although this has not been proven.

Genes alone are not responsible for GPA because it's very unusual for\u00a02 people in the same family to have it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Information about you", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service

If you have GPA, your clinical team will pass information about you on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

The NCARDRS helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat GPA. You can opt out of the register at any time.

GOV.UK has more information about the register

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger)", "alternateName": ["Whitlow finger"]}, "description": "Find out about herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger) including symptoms, causes and treatments.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/herpetic-whitlow/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-11-06T01:00:00+00:00", "2023-11-06T01:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/herpetic-whitlow/", "name": "Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-20T18:40:47+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/herpetic-whitlow/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger)"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger) is a painful infection of the finger caused by the herpes virus. It's easily treated but can come back.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check if you have herpetic whitlow

A herpetic whitlow can appear anywhere on your finger, but it usually affects the top of your finger (fingertip).

Symptoms of herpetic whitlow include:

  • swelling and pain in your finger
  • blisters or sores on your finger
  • skin becoming red or darker than your usual skin tone
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "A finger with red lumps under the skin filled with fluid", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/S_0917_Herpetic-whitlow_M1700211.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY\r\n\r\nhttps://www.sciencephoto.com/media/257432/view", "datePublished": "2017-09-26T15:33:40+00:00", "keywords": []}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if you think you have herpetic whitlow

Treatment is more effective if started early and will help stop the infection spreading.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment from a GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment from a GP

You may be prescribed antiviral tablets if you see a GP within 48 hours of your symptoms showing.

Antiviral tablets can help your finger to heal more quickly.

If you cannot see a GP within 48 hours, the infection will go away without treatment within 2 to 4 weeks. But there are things you can do yourself to help.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Things you can try", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can do to help herpetic whitlow

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • keep your finger clean and covered with a dressing

  • take painkillers such as ibuprofen or paracetamol to ease the pain

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not touch your finger \u2013 the infection can spread easily

  • do not touch other parts of your body or other people with your infected finger

  • do not try to drain the fluid \u2013 this can cause the infection to spread

  • do not use contact lenses \u2013 you could spread the infection to your eye

"}, {"position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

If your infection gets worse

Go back to the GP if your infection gets worse or if you have a very high temperature (you feel hot and shivery).

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of herpetic whitlow

Herpetic whitlow is caused by a virus called herpes simplex. You can get it if you touch a cold sore or blister of another infected person.

You're more likely to get herpetic whitlow if you've had cold sores or genital herpes.

You may also get it if you have a weakened immune system \u2013 for example, if you have diabetes or you're having chemotherapy.

The first time you have herpetic whitlow will usually be the most severe.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Prevention", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Herpetic whitlow can come back

Once you have the virus, it stays in your body for the rest of your life.

The condition is rare, but if you get it once you can get it again. For example, it might come back if you have a cut or sore on your finger, or if you're feeling stressed or unwell.

There's not much you can do to prevent herpetic whitlow but it can be treated in the same way if it comes back.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Unintentional weight loss:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Unintentional weight loss", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Unintentional weight loss", "alternateName": ["Weight loss (unexpected)"]}, "description": "Sudden, noticeable weight loss can often happen after a stressful event like a divorce, redundancy or bereavement. In some cases it can also be a sign of a serious illness.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/unintentional-weight-loss/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-02-01T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-02-01T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/unintentional-weight-loss/", "name": "Unintentional weight loss", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-02-26T12:58:31+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/unintentional-weight-loss/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Unintentional weight loss"}], "keywords": ["Coeliac disease", "Weight loss"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Sudden, noticeable weight loss can happen after a stressful event, although it can also be a sign of a serious illness.

It's normal to lose a noticeable amount of weight after the stress of changing jobs, divorce, redundancy or bereavement.

Weight often returns to normal when you start to feel happier, after you've had time to grieve or get used to the change. Counselling and support may be needed to help you get to this stage.

Significant weight loss can also be the result of an eating disorder, such as anorexia or bulimia. If you think you have an eating disorder, talk to someone you trust and consider speaking to your GP. There are also several organisations that can provide you with information and advice, such as the eating disorders charity Beat.

If your weight loss wasn't due to one of the causes mentioned, and you didn't lose weight through dieting or exercising, see your GP, as you may have an illness that needs treating.

The following information may give you a better idea of the cause of your weight loss, but don't use it to diagnose yourself. Always see a GP for a proper diagnosis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How much weight loss is a concern?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How much weight loss is a concern?

Your body weight can regularly fluctuate, but the persistent, unintentional loss of more than 5% of your weight over 6 to 12 months is usually a cause for concern. Losing this much weight can be a sign of malnutrition, where a person's diet doesn't contain the right amount of nutrients.

You should pay particular attention if you experience other symptoms, such as:

  • tiredness
  • loss of appetite
  • a change in your toilet habits
  • an increase in illnesses or infections
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Other common causes of unexpected weight loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Other common causes of unexpected weight loss

Unintentional weight loss does not always have an identifiable underlying cause but, in addition to the causes already mentioned, it's often the result of:

  • depression 
  • an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism), or over-treating an underactive thyroid
  • cancer
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Less common causes of unexpected weight loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Less common causes of unexpected weight loss

Less frequently, unexpected weight loss may be the result of:

  • the side effects of certain medications
  • alcohol misuse or drug misuse 
  • heart, kidney, lung or liver disease
  • a problem with the glands that secrete hormones – such as Addison's disease or undiagnosed diabetes
  • a long-term inflammatory condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus
  • dental problems – such as losing teeth, having new orthodontics, or mouth ulcers
  • a condition that causes dysphagia (swallowing problems)
  • a problem with the gut, such as a stomach ulcer, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis or coeliac disease
  • a bacterial, viral or parasitic infection, such as persistent gastroenteritis, tuberculosis (TB) or HIV and AIDS
  • dementia – people with dementia may be unable to communicate their eating needs
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Warts and verrucas:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Warts and verrucas", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Warts and verrucas", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about warts and verrucas, which are small lumps on the skin. Find out what causes warts and verrucas, how they're treated and when to get medical help.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/warts-and-verrucas/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-10-14T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-10-14T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/warts-and-verrucas/", "name": "Warts and verrucas", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-16T15:38:00+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/warts-and-verrucas/#overview", "description": "Warts and verrucas are small lumps on the skin caused by a virus. They spread easily though skin contact and touching infected surfaces.", "text": "

The main symptom of a wart or verruca is a small, rough lump on the skin.

Treatments for a wart or a verruca include creams, plasters and sprays you can get from a pharmacy. A GP may also be able to remove it by freezing it.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/warts-and-verrucas/#symptoms", "description": "The main symptom of a wart or verruca is a small, rough lump on the skin.", "text": "


Warts feel firm and rough. They can appear on palms, knuckles, knees and fingers


Warts are usually skin coloured but may appear darker on dark skin


Verrucas appear on your feet. They have tiny black dots under the hard skin


Some warts are round, flat and can be yellow (plane warts). You can have many of them


Clusters of warts, spread over an area of skin (mosaic warts) are common on feet and hands

Warts do not cause you any harm, but some people find them itchy, painful or embarrassing. Verrucas are more likely to be painful – like standing on a needle.

You can treat warts if they bother you, keep coming back or are painful.

", "title": "Check if you have a wart or verruca"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/warts-and-verrucas/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatments for a wart or a verruca include creams, plasters and sprays you can get from a pharmacy. A GP may also be able to remove it by freezing it.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/warts-and-verrucas/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatments for a wart or a verruca include creams, plasters and sprays you can get from a pharmacy. A GP may also be able to remove it by freezing it.", "text": "

A GP may be able to freeze a wart or verruca so it falls off a few weeks later. Sometimes it takes a few sessions.

Check with the GP if the NHS pays for this treatment in your area.

If treatment has not worked or you have a wart on your face, the GP might refer you to a skin specialist. Other treatments include minor surgery and treatment with laser or light.

", "title": "Treatment from a GP"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/warts-and-verrucas/#self-care", "description": "Treatments for a wart or a verruca include creams, plasters and sprays you can get from a pharmacy. A GP may also be able to remove it by freezing it.", "text": "

Warts and verrucas are caused by a virus. They can be spread to other people from contaminated surfaces or through close skin contact. You're more likely to spread a wart or verruca if your skin is wet or damaged.

It can take months for a wart or verruca to appear after contact with the virus.


Do

  • wash your hands after touching a wart or verruca

  • change your socks daily if you have a verruca

  • cover warts and verrucas with a plaster when swimming

  • take care not to cut a wart when shaving


Don't

  • do not share towels, flannels, socks or shoes if you have a wart or verruca

  • do not bite your nails or suck fingers with warts on

  • do not walk barefoot in public places if you have a verruca

  • do not scratch or pick a wart

", "title": "How to stop warts and verrucas spreading"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/warts-and-verrucas/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Warts and verrucas"}], "keywords": ["Genital warts", "Warts and verrucas", "Virus infections"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Warts and verrucas are small lumps on the skin that most people have at some point in their life. They usually go away on their own but may take months or even years.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Check if you have a wart or verruca", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 1, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "A dark brown wart on the back of a person's hand with a brown skin tone.", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/C0497988-Common_wart.max-600x600.png", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "Science Photo Library https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/1129448/view", "datePublished": "2020-10-07T13:12:54+00:00", "keywords": []}, {"position": 3, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "A collection of flat warts on a person's forehead.", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/m2900129.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "CNRI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/263358/view", "datePublished": "2017-06-22T13:04:41+00:00", "keywords": []}, {"position": 5, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Warts do not cause you any harm, but some people find them itchy, painful or embarrassing. Verrucas are more likely to be painful – like standing on a needle.

You can treat warts if they bother you, keep coming back or are painful.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "A pharmacist can help with warts and verrucas", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You can buy creams, plasters and sprays from pharmacies to treat warts and verrucas.

These treatments can take up to 3 months to complete, may irritate your skin and do not always work. You should not use these treatments on your face.

Your pharmacist can give you advice about the best treatment for you.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Find a service", "identifier": "2", "text": "

Find a pharmacy

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you're worried about a growth on your skin
  • you have a wart or verruca that keeps coming back
  • you have a very large or painful wart or verruca
  • a wart bleeds or changes in how it looks
  • you have a wart on your face or genitals
"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Genital warts can be treated at a sexual health or GUM clinic.

Find your nearest sexual health service

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment from a GP", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A GP may be able to freeze a wart or verruca so it falls off a few weeks later. Sometimes it takes a few sessions.

Check with the GP if the NHS pays for this treatment in your area.

If treatment has not worked or you have a wart on your face, the GP might refer you to a skin specialist. Other treatments include minor surgery and treatment with laser or light.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How to stop warts and verrucas spreading", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Warts and verrucas are caused by a virus. They can be spread to other people from contaminated surfaces or through close skin contact. You're more likely to spread a wart or verruca if your skin is wet or damaged.

It can take months for a wart or verruca to appear after contact with the virus.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • wash your hands after touching a wart or verruca

  • change your socks daily if you have a verruca

  • cover warts and verrucas with a plaster when swimming

  • take care not to cut a wart when shaving

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not share towels, flannels, socks or shoes if you have a wart or verruca

  • do not bite your nails or suck fingers with warts on

  • do not walk barefoot in public places if you have a verruca

  • do not scratch or pick a wart

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}]}
West Nile virus:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "West Nile virus", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "West Nile virus", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about West Nile virus (WNV), a virus spread by mosquitoes that is found in many countries around the world.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/west-nile-virus/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-11-23T01:00:00+00:00", "2023-11-23T01:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/west-nile-virus/", "name": "West Nile virus", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-26T18:08:43+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/west-nile-virus/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "West Nile virus"}], "keywords": ["West Nile Virus", "Travelling outside the European Economic Area"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

West Nile virus (WNV) is spread by mosquitoes in many countries (but not in the UK). There are usually no symptoms and it gets better without treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Who's at risk", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

West Nile virus rarely affects UK travellers

Very few people coming back to the UK have the virus. No one has got the virus while in the UK.

You can check the area you're travelling to on the TravelHealthPro website.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Visiting high-risk areas for WNV

There's no vaccine for WNV. You should avoid mosquito bites when visiting high-risk areas by using insect sprays and mosquito nets.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of WNV

Most people with WNV have no symptoms.

Some people develop mild flu-like symptoms, a skin rash and may feel sick.

The infection usually goes away on its own without treatment.

The virus is not contagious. You only get it from being bitten by an infected mosquito.

People aged over 50 or with another condition, such as cancer, diabetes or hypertension, are more at risk of getting seriously ill.

Signs of a severe infection can include flu-like symptoms and also:

  • muscle weakness
  • confusion
  • fits (seizures)

Severe WNV infections are treated in hospital. In rare cases, it can lead to meningitis and encephalitis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Get medical advice if:

  • you develop symptoms of WNV while you're travelling

Check your travel insurance for how to get medical help while you're away or look up the country you're visiting on GOV.UK.

See a GP if you notice symptoms when you get home

  • make sure you say where you've been travelling
"}]}]}
Whooping cough:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Whooping cough", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Whooping cough", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about the symptoms of whooping cough, who's at risk of the condition, when to get medical advice, and how it's treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/whooping-cough/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-11-13T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-11-13T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/whooping-cough/", "name": "Whooping cough", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-11-25T12:53:15+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/whooping-cough/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Whooping cough"}], "keywords": ["Whooping cough"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Whooping cough (also called pertussis) is a bacterial infection of the lungs and breathing tubes. It spreads very easily.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms of whooping cough", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check if you or your child has whooping cough

The first signs of whooping cough are like a cold.

After about a week, you or your child:

  • will get coughing bouts that last for a few minutes and are worse at night
  • will make a "whoop" sound – a gasp for breath between coughs (young babies and some adults may not "whoop")
  • may bring up a thick mucus, which can make you sick (vomit)
  • may become very red in the face (more common in adults)
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Urgent", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP urgently or call 111 if:

  • your baby is under 6 months old and has symptoms of whooping cough
  • you or your child have a very bad cough that is getting worse
  • you've been in contact with someone with whooping cough and you're pregnant
  • you or your child has been in contact with someone with whooping cough and have a weakened immune system

Whooping cough can spread very easily. It's best to call the GP before you go in. They might suggest talking over the phone.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Whooping cough can be dangerous

Babies under 6 months old have increased chances of problems including:

  • dehydration
  • breathing difficulties
  • pneumonia
  • fits (seizures)

Whooping cough is less severe in older children and adults but coughing may cause problems including:

  • nosebleeds
  • sore ribs
  • hernia
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Emergency", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Call 999 or go to A&E if:

  • your child has periods of stopping breathing and their face or lips go blue (cyanosis)
  • you or your child are finding it hard to breathe properly (shallow breathing)
  • you or your child have chest pain that's worse when breathing or coughing – this could be a sign of pneumonia
  • your child is having fits (seizures)
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment for whooping cough", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for whooping cough

Treatment depends on your age and how long you've had the infection.

If your whooping cough is severe, or your baby is under 6 months old and has whooping cough, you'll usually need treatment in hospital.

If diagnosed within 3 weeks of the infection, you'll be given antibiotics to help stop it spreading to others. Antibiotics may not reduce symptoms.

If you've had whooping cough for more than 3 weeks, you're no longer contagious and do not need antibiotics.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Important

Carry on taking the antibiotics until you've completed the course, even if you feel better.

"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can do yourself to relieve the symptoms of whooping cough

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • get plenty of rest
  • drink lots of fluids
  • take paracetamol or ibuprofen to relieve discomfort
"}, {"position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not give a child under 16 paracetamol and ibuprofen at the same time. Always check first with a GP or pharmacist
  • do not give aspirin to children under 16
  • do not take cough medicines – they're not suitable for young children and do not help with this type of cough
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How long whooping cough is contagious for

You're contagious from about 6 days after the start of cold-like symptoms to 3 weeks after the coughing starts.

If you start antibiotics within 3 weeks of starting to cough, it will reduce the time you're contagious for.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The whooping cough vaccine

The whooping cough vaccine protects babies and children from getting whooping cough. That's why it's important to have all the routine NHS vaccinations.

The vaccine is routinely given as part of:

  • the 6-in-1 vaccine - for babies at 8, 12 and 16 weeks
  • the 4-in-1 pre-school booster – for pre-school children

If you're pregnant you should also have the whooping cough vaccine – ideally between 16 and 32 weeks.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, a heart condition that can cause the heart to beat abnormally fast. Find out about the symptoms, causes and treatments.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/wolff-parkinson-white-syndrome/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-08-13T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-08-13T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/wolff-parkinson-white-syndrome/", "name": "Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2018-08-28T09:15:21+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/wolff-parkinson-white-syndrome/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a relatively common heart condition that causes the heart to beat abnormally fast for periods of time.

The cause is an extra electrical connection in the heart. This problem with the heart is present at birth (congenital), although symptoms may not develop until later in life. Many cases are diagnosed in otherwise healthy young adults.

Sometimes the extra electrical connection won't cause any symptoms and may only be picked up when an electrocardiogram (ECG) test is carried out for another reason. In these cases, further tests will be done to determine if treatment is required.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Is it serious?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Is it serious?

It can be scary to be told that you have a problem with your heart, but WPW syndrome usually isn't serious.

Many people will have no symptoms or only experience occasional, mild episodes of their heart racing. With treatment, the condition can normally be completely cured.

WPW syndrome can sometimes be life-threatening, particularly if it occurs alongside a type of irregular heartbeat called atrial fibrillation. But this is rare and treatment can eliminate this risk.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms of WPW syndrome", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of WPW syndrome

If you have WPW syndrome, you may experience episodes where your heart suddenly starts racing, before stopping or slowing down abruptly. This rapid heart rate is called supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).

During an episode, you may experience symptoms such as:

  • a pounding or fluttering heartbeat (heart palpitations)
  • feeling light-headed or dizzy
  • shortness of breath
  • chest pain
  • sweating
  • feeling anxious
  • finding physical activity exhausting
  • passing out (fainting)

These episodes can last for seconds, minutes or hours.

How often they occur varies from person to person. Some people may have episodes on a daily basis, while others may only experience them a few times a year.

They normally occur randomly, without any identifiable cause, but they can sometimes be triggered by strenuous exercise or drinking a lot of alcohol or caffeine.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When to seek medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to seek medical advice

See a GP if you keep getting a fast heartbeat. It's important to get it checked out in case it could be something serious.

Dial 999 for an ambulance if:

  • your heartbeat doesn't go back to normal in a few minutes
  • you have chest pain that lasts more than 15 minutes – you may also have pain in your arms, back or jaw
  • you have chest pain and other symptoms like feeling sick, being sick (vomiting), shortness of breath or sweating
  • someone passes out (faints) and doesn't regain consciousness

If you've been diagnosed with WPW syndrome and you experience an episode, first try the techniques you've been taught or take any medication you've been given.

Dial 999 or go to your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department if these measures don't stop the episode within a few minutes, or if someone you know has WPW syndrome and collapses or faints.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What causes WPW syndrome?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes WPW syndrome?

When the heart beats, its muscular walls contract (tighten and squeeze) to force blood out and around the body. They then relax, allowing the heart to fill with blood again. This is controlled by electrical signals.

In WPW syndrome, there's an extra electrical connection in the heart, which allows electrical signals to bypass the usual route and form a short circuit. This means the signals travel round and round in a loop, causing episodes where the heart beats very fast.

The extra electrical connection is caused by a strand of heart muscle that grows while the unborn baby is developing in the womb.

It's not clear exactly why this happens. It just seems to occur randomly in some babies, although rare cases have been found to run in families.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Diagnosing WPW syndrome", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diagnosing WPW syndrome

If your doctor thinks you might have WPW syndrome after assessing your symptoms, they'll probably recommend having an electrocardiogram (ECG) and will refer you to a cardiologist (heart specialist).

An ECG is a test that records your heart's rhythm and electrical activity. Small discs called electrodes are stuck onto your arms, legs and chest and connected by wires to an ECG machine. The machine records the tiny electrical signals produced by your heart each time it beats.

If you have WPW syndrome, the ECG will record an unusual pattern that isn't usually present in people who don't have the condition.

To confirm the diagnosis, you may be asked to wear a small portable ECG recorder so your heart rhythm can be recorded during an episode. The recorder will trace your heart rate continuously over a few days, or when you switch it on at the start of an episode.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatments for WPW syndrome", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments for WPW syndrome

In many cases, episodes of abnormal heart activity associated with WPW syndrome are harmless, don't last long, and settle down on their own without treatment.

You may therefore not need any treatment if your symptoms are mild or occur very occasionally, although you should still have regular check-ups so your heart can be monitored.

If your cardiologist recommends treatment, there are a number of options available. You can have treatment to either stop episodes when they occur, or prevent them occurring in the future.

Stopping an episode

There are 3 main techniques and treatments that can help stop episodes as they occur. These are:

  • Vagal manoeuvres – techniques designed to stimulate the nerve that slows down the electrical signals in your heart. An example is the "Valsalva manoeuvre", where you hold your nose, close your mouth and exhale hard while straining as if you're on the toilet.
  • Medication – an injection of medicine such as adenosine can be given in hospital if vagal manoeuvres don't help. It can block the abnormal electrical signals in your heart.
  • Cardioversion – a type of electric shock therapy that jolts the heart back into a normal rhythm. This may be carried out in hospital if the above treatments don't work.

Preventing further episodes

Techniques and treatments that can help prevent episodes include:

  • Lifestyle changes – if your episodes are triggered by things such as strenuous exercise or alcohol, avoiding these may help. Your cardiologist can advise you about this.
  • Catheter ablation – this procedure is commonly used nowadays to destroy the extra part of the heart causing the problems in the heart's electrical system. It's effective in around 95% of cases.
  • Medication – daily tablets of medication such as amiodarone can help prevent episodes by slowing down the electrical impulses in your heart.

See treating supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) for more information about all the treatments mentioned here.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Farting (flatulence):

Farting is usually only a problem if you feel you fart a lot or you also have other symptoms, like bleeding from your bottom.

Exercising regularly and changing your diet can help reduce farting. Get advice from a GP if it does not get better or you also have other symptoms.

Excessive or smelly farting is often caused by swallowing air or eating foods that are difficult to digest.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/flatulence/#symptoms", "description": "Farting is usually only a problem if you feel you fart a lot or you also have other symptoms, like bleeding from your bottom.", "text": "

Farting is usually nothing to worry about. Everyone farts, some people more than others. The average is 5 to 15 times a day.

What's normal is different for everyone. If you notice a change or it's affecting your life, there are things you can do.

Get advice from a GP if it does not get better or you also have other symptoms.", "text": "

Do

  • eat smaller meals, more often

  • drink or chew food slowly

  • exercise regularly to improve how your body digests food

  • drink peppermint tea


Don't

  • do not chew gum, smoke, or suck pen tops or hard sweets to avoid swallowing air

  • do not wear loose-fitting dentures

  • do not eat too many foods that are difficult to digest and make you fart

", "title": "A pharmacist can help with excessive or smelly farts"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/flatulence/#causes", "description": "Excessive or smelly farting is often caused by swallowing air or eating foods that are difficult to digest.", "text": "

Excessive or smelly farts can be caused when you swallow air or eat foods that are difficult to digest. It can also sometimes be a sign of a health condition.

Do not self-diagnose. See a GP if you're worried about your farting.

Symptoms: Difficulty pooing
Possible causes: Constipation

Symptoms: Bloating, stomach pain with diarrhoea or constipation that comes and goes
Possible causes: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

Symptoms: Indigestion, constipation, diarrhoea and stomach pain
Possible causes: Coeliac disease

Symptoms: Diarrhoea, bloating, stomach pain, feeling sick
Possible causes: Lactose intolerance

Excessive or smelly wind can also be a side effect of some medicines, including:

  • non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS), like ibuprofen
  • some laxatives
  • antifungal medicines
  • statins

Do not stop or change your medicine without speaking to a GP first.

Leptospirosis (Weil's disease):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Leptospirosis (Weil's disease)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Leptospirosis (Weil's disease)", "alternateName": ["Weil's disease"]}, "description": "Leptospirosis is an infection that's spread by animals. It's rare in the UK.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/leptospirosis/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-09-17T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-09-17T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/leptospirosis/", "name": "Leptospirosis (Weil's disease)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-21T12:12:31+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/leptospirosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Leptospirosis (Weil's disease)"}], "keywords": ["Urine", "weil's disease", "animal pee", "dead animals", "Leptospirosis"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Leptospirosis, also called Weil's disease, is an infection you can get from animals. It's rare in the UK.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How you get leptospirosis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Leptospirosis is spread in the pee of infected animals \u2013 most commonly rats, mice, cows, pigs and dogs.

You can get leptospirosis if:

  • soil or freshwater (such as water from a river, canal or lake) that contains infected pee gets in your mouth, eyes or a cut \u2013 usually during activities like kayaking, outdoor swimming or fishing
  • you touch an infected animal's blood or flesh \u2013 usually from working with animals or animal parts

It's very rare to get leptospirosis from pets, other people or bites.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if you might have been exposed to infected pee and you have:

  • a high temperature, or you feel hot and shivery
  • a headache
  • been feeling sick (nausea), you're being sick, or you have diarrhoea
  • aching muscles and joints
  • red eyes
  • loss of appetite

These are symptoms of leptospirosis.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Urgent", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Ask for an urgent GP appointment if you have:

  • yellow skin and eyes (jaundice)
  • a rash
  • been unable to pee
  • swollen ankles, feet or hands
  • chest pain
  • shortness of breath
  • been coughing up blood

You might have a serious form of the infection that needs to be treated quickly.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment from a GP", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A GP may prescribe antibiotic tablets to treat the infection. Most people recover in a few days or weeks.

It's important to finish the course of antibiotics, even if you start to feel better.

Take paracetamol or ibuprofen to relieve any aches, pains or a high temperature.

If you have a more serious form of the infection, you may need to be treated in hospital.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How to avoid getting leptospirosis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Leptospirosis is rare in the UK. You have a higher chance of getting it if you do outdoor activities like water sports (especially while abroad in tropical areas), or you work with animals or animal parts.

To reduce your chances of getting leptospirosis:

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • wash your hands with soap and water after handling animals or animal products

  • clean any wounds as soon as possible

  • cover any cuts and grazes with waterproof plasters

  • wear protective clothing if you're at risk through your job

  • shower as soon as possible if you've been in potentially infected water

  • check your dog is vaccinated against leptospirosis (there is no vaccine for people)

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not touch water or soil that may contain animal pee

  • do not touch dead animals with your bare hands

  • do not drink water from places like rivers, canals or lakes \u2013 always boil or treat it first

"}]}]}
Watering eyes:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Watering eyes", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Watering eyes", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Watering eyes occur if too many tears are produced or they can't drain away properly.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/watering-eyes/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-04-06T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-04-06T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/watering-eyes/", "name": "Watering eyes", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-11-18T14:20:19+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/watering-eyes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Watering eyes"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Watering eyes are common and often get better on their own, but treatment may be needed if the watering affects your daily activities.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of watering eyes

It's normal for your eyes to water in smoky environments or if you're outside in the cold or wind.

An eye injury or something in your eye, such as an eyelash or a piece of grit, can also make your eyes water.

Sometimes watering eyes can be caused by a condition such as:

  • an allergy or infection (conjunctivitis)
  • blocked tear ducts (small tubes that tears drain into)
  • your eyelid drooping away from the eye (ectropion) or your eyelid turning inwards (entropion)
  • dry eye syndrome – this can cause your eyes to produce too many tears

Babies often have watering eyes because their tear ducts are small. It usually gets better by the time they're 1 year old.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How a pharmacist can help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You can ask a pharmacist about:

  • what you can do to treat it yourself – such as cleaning and protecting your eyes
  • what you can buy to help – such as cleaning solutions, eyedrops or allergy medicines
  • whether you need to see an optician or GP
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Find a service", "identifier": "2", "text": "

Find a pharmacy

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • your eyes keep watering and it's stopping you doing everyday activities
  • you experience any changes to your vision, such as loss of vision
  • your eyelid is turning inwards or drooping away from your eye
  • you have any lumps or swellings around your eyes
  • your eyes are very sore or painful
  • your baby's eyes are sore, red or very watery

If your GP cannot find what's causing your eyes to water, they may refer you to an eye specialist (ophthalmologist) for tests.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for watering eyes

Treatment may not be needed if the watering is not causing problems.

If treatment is needed, it will depend on what the cause is.

For example:

  • eyedrops can help if your eyes are dry or infected
  • medicines can help if you have an allergy
  • anything in your eye, like a piece of grit, can be removed
  • a small operation may be needed if you have a problem with your eyelids or you have blocked tear ducts
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Weight loss surgery:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Weight loss surgery", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Weight loss surgery", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Weight loss surgery is sometimes used as a treatment for people who are very obese. It can lead to significant weight loss and help improve many obesity-related conditions, such as type 2 diabetes or high blood pressure.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/weight-loss-surgery/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-04-14T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-04-14T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/weight-loss-surgery/", "name": "Weight loss surgery", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-04-20T14:00:51+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/weight-loss-surgery/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Weight loss surgery", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/weight-loss-surgery/who-can-have-it/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Availability"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/weight-loss-surgery/types/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Types"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/weight-loss-surgery/afterwards/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Afterwards"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/weight-loss-surgery/risks/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Risks"}], "keywords": ["Obesity", "Obesity surgery"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Weight loss surgery, also called bariatric or metabolic surgery, is sometimes used as a treatment for people who are very obese.

It can lead to significant weight loss and help improve many obesity-related conditions, such as\u00a0type 2 diabetes or high blood pressure.

But it's a major operation and in most cases should only be considered after trying to\u00a0lose weight through\u00a0a healthy diet\u00a0and exercise.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "NHS\u00a0weight loss surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

NHS\u00a0weight loss surgery

Weight loss surgery is available on the NHS if:

  • you have a\u00a0body mass index (BMI) of 40 or more, or a BMI between 35 and 40 and an obesity-related condition that\u00a0might improve\u00a0if you lost weight (such as\u00a0type 2 diabetes or high blood pressure)
  • you've tried all other weight loss methods, such as dieting and exercise, but have struggled to lose\u00a0weight or keep it off
  • you agree to long-term follow-up\u00a0after surgery\u00a0\u2013 such as\u00a0making healthy lifestyle changes and attending regular check-ups

Speak to a GP if you think weight loss surgery may be an option for you. If you qualify for NHS treatment, they can refer you for an assessment to check surgery is suitable.

You can also pay for surgery privately, although this can be expensive.

Read more about\u00a0NHS and private weight loss surgery.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Types\u00a0of weight loss surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types\u00a0of weight loss surgery

There are several types of weight loss surgery.

The most common types are:

  • gastric band\u00a0\u2013 a band is placed around your stomach, so you do not need to eat as much to feel full
  • gastric bypass\u00a0\u2013 the top part of your stomach is joined to the small intestine, so you feel fuller\u00a0sooner and do not absorb as many calories from food
  • sleeve gastrectomy\u00a0\u2013\u00a0some of your stomach is removed,\u00a0so\u00a0you cannot eat as much as you could before and you'll feel\u00a0full sooner

All these operations can lead to significant weight loss within a few years, but each has advantages and disadvantages.

If you're considering weight loss surgery, speak to a surgeon about the different types available to help decide which is best for you.

Read more about the types of weight loss surgery.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Life after weight loss surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Life after weight loss surgery

Weight loss surgery can achieve dramatic weight loss, but it's not a cure for obesity on its own.

You'll\u00a0need to commit to making permanent lifestyle changes after surgery to avoid putting weight back on.

You'll need to:

  • change your diet\u00a0\u2013 you'll\u00a0be on\u00a0a liquid or soft food diet in the weeks after surgery,\u00a0but will\u00a0gradually move onto a normal balanced diet\u00a0that you need to\u00a0stay on for life
  • exercise regularly\u00a0\u2013\u00a0once you've recovered from surgery, you'll be advised to start an exercise plan and continue it for life
  • attend regular follow-up appointments to check how things are going after surgery and get advice or support\u00a0if you need it

Women who have weight loss surgery will also usually need to avoid becoming pregnant during the first 12 to 18 months after surgery.

Read more about life after weight loss surgery.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Risks\u00a0of weight loss surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Risks\u00a0of weight loss surgery

Weight loss surgery carries a small risk of complications.

These include:

  • being left with excess folds of skin\u00a0\u2013 you may need\u00a0further surgery\u00a0to remove these and it is not usually available free of charge on the NHS
  • not getting enough\u00a0vitamins and minerals from your diet\u00a0\u2013 you'll probably need to take supplements for the rest of your life after surgery
  • gallstones\u00a0(small, hard stones that form in the gallbladder)
  • a blood clot in the leg (deep vein thrombosis) or lungs (pulmonary embolism)
  • the gastric band slipping out of place, food leaking from the join between the stomach and small intestine, or the gut becoming blocked or narrowed

Before having surgery, speak to your surgeon about the possible benefits and risks of the procedure.

Read\u00a0more about the\u00a0risks of weight loss surgery.
